definition: enough and to spare (idiom)
to grab/to snatch up/variant of 焯[chao1]
generous/ample/wide/spacious/well-off/to grip
to grab/to snatch up/variant of 焯[chao1]
generous/ample/wide/spacious/well-off/to grip
to have/there is/there are/to exist/to be
extra/surplus/remaining/remainder after division/(following numerical value) or more/in excess of (some number)/residue (math.)/after/I/me
surname Yu
(archaic) I/me/variant of 餘|余[yu2], surplus

sentences.english: Two significant digits is good enough.
sentences.chinese: 个有效数应该绰绰有余了。

sentences.english: Don't worry about daily expenses, we have enouh and to spare.
sentences.chinese: 不必担心日常开支，我们绰绰有余。

sentences.english: As he does so, Skiles has been enjoying the luxury of time.
sentences.chinese: 眼下，斯科尔斯的时间绰绰有余，他很从容。

sentences.english: The big tables enable all books to be laid out with ease.
sentences.chinese: 这些桌子很大，把所有的书摊在上面还绰绰有余。

sentences.english: There were eight or ten; and there was abundance of room for them in our great pilot-house.
sentences.chinese: 约有八到十人吧，我们的大驾驶室容纳他们绰绰有余。

sentences.english: For a sales meeting, two or three people are more than enough.
sentences.chinese: 对销售会议来说，两三个人就绰绰有余了。

richly provided for/having enough and to spare

at most/at best
acceptable/passable/justifiable/(of a course of action) to make sense
couldn't be better/ideal/wonderful
at most/at best
using a talented person in an insignificant position (idiom)/a sledgehammer to crack a nut
up to the maximum/upper limit/at most
insignificant/trifling/merely

not bad/OK
to not lack
no problem
